div.p: 1. IV. Monday.

Summer is at length disclosing itself in its appropriate character— We had Fahrenheit’s Thermometer at 90 which has not happened before since April; or the first week in May. My Son Charles left us to pay a visit at Medford— I have finished reading the Book of Numbers in Mr Thomson’s version of the Septuagint, and begun upon that of Deuteronomy— I loitered much of the morning in my garden and nursery; but was compelled by the heat of the Sun to suspend my labour of weeding— At noon I went and bathed at Mr Greenleaf’s wharf— Swam about five Minutes— First Sea-water bath for this Season, and I took J. Kirk with me— After dinner I rode with Mrs Adams and Louisa, to Dorchester, and visited Mr and Mrs Bailey— Returned by Neponset Bridge— Mr Sullivan the new purchaser of Germantown came here while I was gone to the Bath, but I did not see him.— The Bath gave me a drowsy spell before and after dinner, and thus absorbed much of my leisure— I received a Letter from R. Rush, with a copy of his book, upon his Residence in England— Moon eclipsed this Evening
2. IV:20. Tuesday.

It is said that Fahrenheit’s Thermometer was at 90 yesterday in Boston. The heat was not quite so intense this day and there was a fresh breeze, to serve as a continual fan— There was a man here by the name of Branch from Mansfield, Connecticut, a maker of silk, who came to persuade Mrs Adams to purchase some of his Silks; but they were not inviting— I took however an ounce of his White Mulberry seed though it is a full Month too late for sowing them.— I planted some Elm-seed in one of my earthen pots, and about ten of them came up; but they do not grow so well there as in the open ground. I took them out therefore and planted them in the open ground, and filling the pot with fresh earth, buried in it six Mazzard Cherries steeped in rum— I have some equivocal evidence, that the steeping in rum does not destroy the germ, and I wish now to ascertain the fact— I planted also a number of large Ohio Walnuts, and black-heart Cherry Stones—both with little promise— Mr Deane says that the Stone of no cherry from a graft or bud will ever come up, and this my own experience confirms— Yet I continue to plant many— The Mazzard is the only cherry I have been able to raise from the Stone— I found one Hickory Walnut up this Morning, and the seed leaves of one grape— My apple bud shoot is now 32 inches long, continuing to grow at the rate of 1/2 an inch a day— I bathed and swam about 10 minutes at D. Greenleaf’s wharf— I was hoarse in the Evening, and suspect I must soon renounce my Sea-bathing and swimming altogether—or must make it a rule to restore the suspended perspiration by exercise, after coming out of the Bath.— President Jackson has been obliged by the feeble state of his health, to give up the remainder of his tour; and from Concord in New Hampshire, yesterday returned through Lowell, to Roxbury, without passing through Boston— He lodged last Night at the House of Mr Bradford, one of his partizans in Roxbury; to proceed this day to Providence; thence in the Steam-boat to New-York; and intending to reach Washington on Thursday— And so ends this magnificent Tour— But whether from real disease, crafty sickness or the collisions of rival servility between the two parties in New-Hampshire, is yet uncertain— Perhaps a little of all three.
3. IV. Wednesday.

The change of weather, or my exposure in the Garden and Nursery, or my Sea-water bath, I fear this last more than any thing else, has thrown my habitual inflammation up into my throat, and I was this day exceedingly hoarse— The morning lowered, and it began raining about ten O’Clock, and rained with little intermission, almost the whole day. My Son Charles came out from Boston, before dinner and remains at present with us— His wife
and child are still at Medford, and the child has been these two days unwell— I planted a row of white, garden Strawberries of Ohio Walnuts and of black heart Cherry-Stones, where I take it for granted nothing but the Strawberries will come up— The growth of all my seedling plants of the present year is excessively slow, and those which promised best are attacked by Insects— The Elms are more thrifty than the rest. I spent the afternoon reading MacMahon’s instructions for the management of the Garden and Nursery— My own observation though attentive appears yet to have given me no profitable instruction—
4. IV. Thursday. 57th. Anniversary of Independence.

I awoke before One O’Clock this morning with a high fever, and a sore throat, so much obstructed that I found it very difficult to swallow— I thought of rousing the family, but was shortly relieved by a free perspiration, and without sleeping again rose at four— The hoarseness continued nearly the whole day and turned at last to the regular Catarrhal cough— I planted a row of White Mulberry seeds, with Ohio Walnuts and Red Strawberries— Captain Souther and Mr Brigham called upon me to converse with me upon the assessment on me for my Parish tax I was assessed last year near 300 dollars for the parish tax alone, and was here to attend on public worship little more than 3 Months of the year— They assessed me 46 dollars for the Mount Wollaston Estate— Alpheus Spear rents it upon a lease by which he is bound to pay all the taxes upon it—he refuses to pay the assessment upon it—alledging that he is assessed for the same Estate to the Universalist Church and Society where he attends— The Estate is of course taxed twice—once to him, and once to me— I therefore declined the payment of the tax, and it remains unpaid— They are now about to make the assessment for the present year, and came to discuss the matter with me— The plain matter of fact is that by the Laws of this Commonwealth all a man’s Estate within the Commonwealth may be at the will of the Assessors taxed to support the Religious Society to which he belongs— It is the tything system in its worst form— There is an Amendment to the Constitution, which has twice past both Houses of the Legislature, and is to be acted upon by the People next November.— There is no doubt it will be adopted, and then all support of public worship will be voluntary— Captain Souther told me that any abatement of my tax would cause great uneasiness in the parish, because there were other Estates in the same condition, which they would also be obliged to abate, and there must be a re-assessment upon others. I told him that to avoid all uneasiness I would pay the tax, and must of course pay the assessment for the present year: but I should leave the Church and Society, considering it an imposition to which I ought no longer to submit— They said they should be extremely unwilling that I should leave the Society, and wished to do no injustice in the assessment— I told them I fully believed it illegal—for that Spear, the tenant belonging to the Universalist Church and Society their Assessors had a right to assess him, and had assessed him for the Estate— He has paid therefore one Parish tax, and ought not in Justice to be required to pay a second— He refuses to pay it, and I do not choose to sue him at law, for what I think he ought not in Justice to be bound to pay— The real question at Law is between the two sets of Assessors, both of which cannot legally assess the same Estate; but neither Spear nor I ought to be parties to the suit— Captain Souther told me last Summer that he would take the opinion of judge Jackson upon the case— He said now that he had called upon Judge Jackson for that purpose, but he was not at home— We parted without coming to any further agreement, and I am to be spunged once more in the taxes of the present year. Captain Souther also gave me notice that I should be charged for the wood-lot which I purchased
last year of James Baxter, and for the land in Braintree which was my brothers. He said Mr Gourgas had told them it must be charged not to the heirs of my Brother— Mr Joseph Angier was here this afternoon; he had come from Medford this morning with Mrs Angier— I walked to Mrs T. B. Adams’s, where were Mrs Angier the Mother, Mrs John Angier; Louisa C. Smith, Mr Beale, his Son and eldest daughter, John Quincy Adams junr and a Son of the late John Law, of Washington. After a Song or two from Mrs Angier and Joseph, we came home— I heard the distant cannonading and Bells at Boston for the celebration of the day; but it has been no festival to me— A day of gloomy thoughts, desponding anticipations, and self reproaches for useless waste of time.
5. IV:30. Friday.

Clear and fine day—not oppressively warm— Charles went to Boston, and thence goes to Medford till Monday. My wife was very unwell the whole day chiefly confined to her chamber. I spent three Morning hours in my garden and Nursery, and notwithstanding my Catarrhal cough bathed and swam again at D. Greenleaf’s wharf between 1. and 2. O’Clock— It was this day beneficial. I have many subjects of business pressing upon my attention which I totally neglect, for my seedling plants and experiments— I planted in my Nursery a Row of Red, and a separate row of White Strawberries of the common Scarlets intending to cover the ground with Plants from the seed— One of my Willows; the stem from the Cellar, set out in the garden had put forth leaves luxuriantly, but they are destroyed by a small white worm— My seedling Apples are covered and their growth is arrested by the green aphides or lice— I have this day a new fruit to attempt raising from the seed— The black mulberry, and I planted a row of seeds of the White Mulberry, with Ohio Walnuts and steeped Cherries— I have two seedling plants growing, not knowing what they are— One a tree in the Garden— The other a weed in the Nursery— I took it last October out of a box where I had planted Currants, Black berries and grapes— I took it for a Blackberry Vine and have so considered it, till within a fortnight, but it has grown up totally different, and now bears a small yellow blossom. What it is and how it got into my box are mysteries— Towards Evening I took a short walk, and then re-examined the trial of Ephraim K. Avery.
6. IV. Saturday— Parish Meeting.

Morning hours in the Nursery and Garden— Experiments with Mazzard Cherry Stone, and Black-Mulberry— Sun too powerful for digging— Having found my bath yesterday beneficial I repeated it before dinner this day; but the Sun was intensely ardent— The tide not up, the atmosphere calm, the water at the wharves so much soiled that I was obliged to go in at the shelving bank, where the green blood sucking Salt-water fly was annoying— Yet was the bath refreshing— The Parish Meeting of 13. May had been adjourned to 4 O’Clock this afternoon— I went soon after to the town Hall, and about six O’Clock there was a meeting of 18 or 20 persons. Little had been done, in consequence of the votes of 13. May— The Treasurer G. W. Beale had been very remiss in the performance of his duties— A Committee of two John Souther, and Harvey Field, were joined to the Treasurer to carry round the Subscription paper, to collect money to pay the other part of the Parish debt, and report to another adjournment of the Meeting; which was fixed for the second Monday in August at 5. O’Clock in the afternoon; to which all the business adjourned over to this time was again referred. Mr Beale had not got even my written proposal to report; and when called for he reported it verbally— Beale is an acute and attentive and very active person, in whatever concerns his own interest; and equally careless and inattentive, as Treasurer of a Religious Congregation involved in debt. In such
Societies every thing is slightingly done. I have hitherto had little experience of them, and wish to have as little as possible in future— As Moderator of the Meeting of 13 May I was so, by the general usage at this adjournment— Noah Curtis paid me the Rent of Goose Pasture, and Levi Humphrey tax collector for Braintree called on me for a tax of 66 cents highway tax, for the woodlot I bought last October of James Baxter— He told me as a friend, that there were Cattle pasturing upon it which ruined the growing young wood;—and said there were sundry persons in Braintree, who always kept their Cattle in Summer, in the highways, or in their neighbour’s Pastures. He advised me to look to it— I spoke to Mr Gourgas about the tax on the Land that was my brothers in Braintree, and he said he would call upon me, Monday Morning.— Walking homewards with Mr Thomas Greenleaf I asked him to step into my Nursery and look at the plant, which I have raised for a Blackberry vine to tell me, if he knew what it was— He could not tell— Mrs Adams was confined to her chamber.
7. IV:20. Sunday.

Mr Whitney the Minister of the Parish, preached this morning from Colossians 1.15. [“]Who is the image of the invisible God, the first born of every Creature: 16. for by him were all things created that are in heaven, and that are in Earth, visible and invisible, whether they be thrones or dominions, or principalities or powers: all things were created by him and for him: 17. and he is before all things, and by him all things consist; 18. And he is the head of the body, the Church: who is the beginning, the first born from the dead; that in all things he might have that pre-eminence: 19. For it pleased the father that in him should all fulness dwell.”— The afternoon text was from Romans 2.6. “Who shall render to every man according to his deeds.”— Both these discourses were upon Subjects now much controverted—the former with the Orthodox Calvinists, upon the character and person of Christ; and the latter with the Universalists upon the doctrine of future retribution.— Mr Whitney gave his impressions upon both these Subjects as far as he understood them himself— There were two female children baptised this afternoon—the first baptisms since I came home— It seems to be going out of practice to baptise children at all—both these must have been nine or ten Months old— This is one of the numerous evil signs of the decay of religious worship which I have observed within these three or four years. I read the 9th. Sermon of the 3d. Volume of Saurin, being the Second upon Proverbs 23.23. on the Sale of Truth— These two Sermons are admirable— Though in the text there seems to be some incongruity; for if the truth is bought it must be sold— Wherever there is a buyer there must be a Seller, and if the precept not to sell the truth is of universal application, no man can enjoy the benefit of the purchase, but by the violation of the rule on the part of the Seller— Coll. and Mrs Quincy paid us a visit this Evening— Also my namesake and nephew, who is yet here in vacation from Medford—
8. IV. Monday.

Finished reading the Book of Deuteronomy in Charles Thomson’s version of the Septuagint Bible and began upon the Book of Joshua— The heat of the weather was intense— Fahrenheit in State Street Boston at 96. and to me so oppressive that I was compelled to be almost the whole day upon my bed— Yet I spent two hours of the morning in my Garden, where the wild thimbleberry and my Seedling Strawberry, are ripening at the same time— From this day I date their maturity— I have two kinds of seedling grapes, one
native and one foreign, but whether either of them will survive the Summer is doubtful— I read a few Chapters of Mr Rush’s Volume, upon his Residence as Minister of the United States at London; of which he has sent me a copy— I read also two or three Chapters of Basnage’s History of the Jews— Upon the subject of Angels, and the ideas which the Jews entertained of them— Curious matter—but treated by him in a manner which leaves it a question whether he is joking or in earnest— Charles sent me a blank Quit-claim Deed for me to execute, to convey to William Lovering, a small parcel of real Estate in Boston, which was conveyed to me, by the late Thomas Welsh junr. in 1829.—1/8 part of a lot of about 2000 feet with buildings upon it in High Street, Boston— Charles himself came out from Boston this Evening, and read us an Article in the North American Review, upon Phrenology— There was distant Thunder and a sprinkling of rain this Evening, but a sultry Stagnation of Atmosphere in which I gasp for breath and sink into helpless idleness.
9. IV. Tuesday

The Morning was yet warm, and soon after rising I bathed and swam about five minutes at Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s wharf, with my Catarrhal Cough still upon me. I executed the Quit-Claim deed, to William Lovering, as did my wife to renounce her dower, and I took the Deed to Mr T. Greenleaf to acknowledge it— After which I went with him and saw his Son E. Price Greenleaf’s Nursery of Seedling plants— All made by himself upon ground reclaimed from bushes on the border of a running brook behind the house— All done by young Greenleaf with his own hands, and a work truly stupendous, a notable example of what can be done by one man, with industry, resolution, and Perseverance— He has undertaken it within two or three years, and his seedling trees are none of them over two years, old—they are of course yet very small, and will be subject to multitudes of accidents and disasters—but with Perseverance he will have a result— I hope a profitable one to himself— While I was viewing his plantations and his fathers other grounds, Charles who had made an appointment in Boston, to deliver my deed at 11. O’Clock, became impatient, and followed me to Mr Greenleaf’s.— There were two or three light Showers of rain, and towards Evening it cleared away cool— I visited my Garden and Nursery after dinner, but the Summer heat disqualifies me for labour.— I finished my sixth and last Letter upon the Subject of Free-Masonry to Edward Livingston— This like every thing else of Literary occupation has been much neglected for weeks past, and I rejoice to bring it to a close.
10. IV.5. Wednesday.

Mr Beale came this morning, with a proposal to me, that I should in addition to the offer which I have made to the parish to take the unsold pews, in payment of their debt of 3000 dollars to me, give them the interest due upon the note—that is 180 dollars more— I told him that I would give what should remain of that interest after payment of my parish tax for the year— He said it was exceedingly difficult to raise the money to pay the other portion of the debt, and some of the Parishioners were of opinion that I was making a very profitable bargain by taking the unsold pews for 3000 dollars— I said I would enable such persons to make a still more profitable bargain, for I would transfer mine to them with a deduction of twenty per Cent if they would take it off my hands— Mr Beale complained much of his parish tax and said that the Assessors had valued his House and farm at 11000 dollars, when they were really not worth five— I do not believe that Beale would sell them this day for ten, nor for eleven—but nothing can be more iniquitous than this mode of taxation for Parish rates— It is much worse than Tythes, and has produced its natural consequence, an amendment to the Constitution of the Commonwealth, under which all assessments for the support
of religious worship hereafter will be voluntary— Charles with his wife and child returned from their visit to Medford— I had a visit this afternoon from Mr Benjamin F. Hallett, and Mr Gassett, with whom I had a long conversation upon Masonry and Anti-Masonry— They had also the object of urging me to consent to be nominated by the Antimasonic Convention which is to be held in September next for the Office of Governor of the Commonwealth, which Hallett stated was equally desired by the Anti-Masonic party, and by a portion of the National Republican party— He named particularly the two brothers Everett, Stephen C. Phillips, Stephen White, and D. Webster— Mr Hallett presented to me a variety of considerations especially of public interest to induce me to yield to their wish, which I answered by repeating those which sway my inclination to the contrary. My own conviction is strong that I ought not to yield to this proposal— I cannot see any important interest which requires of me the sacrifice, which it would demand, of inclination, of feeling, and of judgment. Mr Hallett said Alexander H. Everett had promised him, that he would see and converse with me very shortly, upon this Subject— My own judgment is against it, and I wish I may have firmness to adhere to it— Mr Hallett spoke of the probability that Marcus Morton might be elected, and said that some of the National Republican party had made proposals to Mr William Baylies who had declined on the ground that Mr Morton had prior pretensions— Mr Gassett told me that the Anti Masons had written a Letter to General La Fayette and were expecting his answer— That Mr Edward Everett had been invited to attend the recent Anti-Masonic Meeting at Concord and had written an answer which would be published— And that Hallett had written a Letter to Poinsett while he was here which Poinsett has not answered— Bright Northern light this Evening.
11. IV:10. Thursday.

I this day commence upon the sixty-seventh year of my age, and am approaching very close upon the limits allotted to long life— Three score years and ten is the term of duration allotted to a sound and vigorous constitution That term I have very nearly gone through, and have no right to expect a longer lease. I would I could flatter myself that I should improve to useful purpose the remainder of days that may be allowed me; but I have so often prayed for aid from above, and so often by my own inefficiency wasted the time and means with which I have been indulged, that I dare no longer pray. My wife was confined the greatest part of this day to her chamber and her bed. I planted Walnuts, cherries, Mulberry seeds black and white, thimble-berry seeds, and nursery Seedling Strawberries in a row at the bottom of the Nursery; together with a number of Ohio Walnuts— I have one Peach-tree there, now of the third years growth, and three cherries of the second— Nothing of the present Season I have filled it with cherry Stones, time after time, with as yet no better result. I have now a great variety of plants growing from nuts seeds and stones of my own planting, and two or three dozen of garden Strawberries just now ripe, are the first fruits of the whole— My growing Currant bushes and grape vines from the seeds are now of the most promising interest, but call yet for a large Stock of Patience— I was yet quite unwell this day: an apology for doing nothing.
12. IV.10. Friday

I went to Cambridge with John Kirk early this morning and attended an examination of the Libraries, and Cabinet of experimental philosophy and chemical apparatus at the university: as a member of a Committee of the board of Overseers— The number of members appointed was nine, only
four of whom were present—Dr William Spooner, Mr Hoare of Concord, judge Samuel P. P. Fay of Cambridge and myself— The absent members were Dr Thaddeus Mason Harris—John R Adan, Revd. John Codman, James T. Austin and Edward Everett. There was not a majority of the Committee present, but those of us who were there went through the examinations— They have for a number of successive years been managed by my Classmate Dr Harris who has been the standing chairman of the Committee— He was so now, but absent from indisposition which devolved the duty upon me— The members of the Committee by two and two examined the alcoves of the library, comparing the numbers of books on some of the shelves with the written catalogue in each Alcove—and they occasionally took out here and there some of the books and inspected their condition— The Cabinet of Experimental Philosophy and the Chemical and Anatomical apartments followed and were duly viewed— The Committee then dined with the President, and some of the Professors and Instructors, and after dinner visited the Dana Law Library, and the Library of the Theological Institution, or Divinity School— They Received written Reports from Dr T. W. Harris the Librarian, Professor Farrar—J. W. Webster, Erving Professor of Chemistry—Charles Sumner, Librarian of the Law Library, and John G. Palfrey, Dean of the Theological Faculty— Every thing was found in good order and condition. There was some question whether any Report could be made by less than a majority of the Committee; and a proposition was made for an adjourned meeting; but I thought this unnecessary and might be difficult to obtain. I proposed to report a short statement of the facts of the examination made by the members of the committee who did attend, annexing to it the several written Reports made to them, which was agreed to— After the examinations were over Dr Spooner and Mr Hoare and myself went with President Quincy to the Mount Auburn Cemetery, and traversed its by-paths— Saw the Monument of Miss Hannah Adams, and that of five infant Children of Judge Story— There were numbers of persons strolling about the avenues—and sundry Tombs in the process of Construction— Returning from Mount Auburn, I alighted at Dr Waterhouses, and spent an hour or two with him in pleasant conversation. He read me a friendly Letter which he had recently received from Mr Madison, and with which he was much delighted— I came home in the Evening, and reached my house just before the ringing of the Bell at nine O’Clock— There was a brilliant Northern Light.
13. V.20. Saturday.

I am suffering with a Catarrhal Cough, ever since the Sore throat and Hoarseness subsided after my first Sea-water bath, and was this day careless and unwell. Solomon Thayer was here this morning— He had a small bundle of his Ray wheat as he now calls it, and says he has 120 bushels of it now ready to be reaped upon an Acre and a half of ground— He thinks that mine failed in both places because it was sown too late, and says he has some which failed in the same manner and from the same cause. He was going with his small bunch of the grain to Boston to make exhibition of it to the Agricultural Society— General Dearborn paid me a Morning visit, and looked over my seedling plants in the garden and Nursery— They have now a trying time with the intense heat of the Sun— And those are most certainly scorched to death, where the weeds that come up round them have been most thoroughly extirpated, and no shading has been substituted in their place— A growth of weeds is therefore sometimes a good shelter— I perceived this day one new black walnut just out of the ground. It is full two Months since the first came up; and hence I infer that the unfolding of their vegetative power differs very much in different nuts— I finished this morning my row of planted seeds, at the bottom of the Nursery—Walnuts, Cherries and Cherry-Stones, and Mulberry Seeds—
with ripe thimbleberries and Strawberries, promiscuously planted. General Dearborn was no better acquainted with my unknown plant than Mr T. Greenleaf— Mr Freeman Hunt was here with the first number of the Penny Magazine, for which he said I had subscribed— It is an English Catchpenny Publication, republished here— My afternoon and evening were uncomfortable.
14. IV.15. Sunday

Midsummer fervors— The Preacher was Mr Smith, the Preceptor of the Academy at Hingham— His morning text was from 1. Thessalonians 5.6. [“]Therefore let us not sleep as do others; but let us watch and be sober.” And upon this text the Sermon was a Dissertation upon the immortality of the Soul— After dinner he preached from Titus 3.9. “But avoid foolish questions, and genealogies and contentions, and strivings about the Law; for they are unprofitable and vain.” The Discourse was an exhortation to Christian harmony— Mr Degrand came out from Boston, and dined and spent the day with us— Mr Beale, with his Son George were here in the Evening— Mrs Adams was confined great part of the day to her bed, with a severe attack of Erisypelas— My own health very indifferent— I read the tenth and last Sermon of Saurin’s 3d. volume on the advantages of Revelation, without sufficient application of mind, and under the conviction that it ought to be read again, and with more care.
15. IV:15. Monday.

Mrs. Adams has an attack extremely violent of the Erisypelas—her face is excessively inflamed and swollen, and she is confined to her bed— My own health as almost universally happens, when she is thus afflicted, proportionally suffers— I slept in the North-eastern upper chamber, and an irresistible lassitude makes me pass great part of the day lying on a bed, and doing nothing— Mr Daniel Hayward a Revolutionary pensioner from Braintree, came and I delivered to him the Certificate of a Pension of 80 dollars a year from the 4th. of March which I had received for him from the Department of War.— Mr Josiah Brigham one of the Assessors of taxes came, and left with me a Letter from Theron Metcalf a lawyer at Dedham; containing his opinion, upon the question concerning the Assessment of Parish taxes, whether upon the owner in fee, or upon the tenant of a leasehold Estate— Mr Metcalfe’s opinion, is contrary to that which Alpheus Spear, told me, he had given him, for it is that the Assessors, can by Law, assess only the owner in fee, and not the Leaseholder—but he speaks very doubtingly, and thinks there is contradiction between the different Statutes of the Commonwealth on the Subject— So there certainly is; and between this question, and that of the Parish debt, how shall I escape a Law-Suit? and worse than a Law suit odious obloquy?— Mr and Mrs Lee paid us a visit this afternoon— About Sunset I visited my Garden and Nursery, and planted a row of Ohio Walnuts, Cherries and Cherry-Stones, and White Mulberry-seeds— Weeds are coming up in profusion— My unknown plant is uprooted—and many of my seedling plants are scorching to cinders— I read some pages of Mr Rush’s Residence at the English Court, brought up to this day the arrears of my Diary-Index; and brooded over the infirmities and miseries of my Condition, to no purpose.
16. IV:15. Tuesday.

David Loud called here this morning, and I delivered to him the Certificate, of his Pension of 80 dollars a year, with which he was not altogether satisfied. He wanted more, and thought he might have proved that he had served two full years, and besides that he was part of the time in an Artillery Company— He was apprehensive too that on presenting his Certificate for payment, he should have to take an Oath which would cost him two
shillings and three pence, or two and sixpence, but he had a mind to dispute the point, and refuse to take the Oath— He had claims also for one of his Sons, who served in the Navy during the late War with Great-Britain— He kept me thus for nearly an hour in Conversation, upon his claims, and on the agreeable news from Europe— I did not know what he meant by this, and asked no explanation; lest he should Discourse upon the wide field of European Politics— Mrs Adams was so ill that we sent for Dr Holbrook who came and prescribed for her this afternoon. Charles went to Boston and returned to dine— The weather was cooler, but I kept house till towards Evening when I visited my Garden and Nursery, and planted a row of Walnuts, Cherry-Stones and White Mulberry Seeds— I found one new and unexpected walnut putting forth its first shoot, from wintered nuts planted since the first of June— Weeds, shooting up with irrepressible luxuriance, and many seedling plants of this year scorched into cinders by the Sun— My labour in the Garden becomes irksome and the loss of my plants mortifying— I took this Evening a very short walk, and read some pages of Mr Rush’s Book. My 6th. and last Letter to the Grand High Priest Edward Livingston, was published in the Boston Daily Advocate, and Boston Press of this day— I commenced writing an Answer to a Letter received from a Committee of an Anti-Masonic Convention held at Montpelier in Vermont the 26th. of last Month.
17. V. Wednesday.

Dr Holbrook was here again, and Mrs Adams continues confined to her bed; though we hope the Crisis of her disorder is past— The heat of the weather has compelled me to suspend my labours in my garden and nursery. I have visited them this week only in the Evening; near Sunset; and already I feel the consequences of insufficient exercise— The Garden and Nursery too already shew the effects of neglecting my daily labour— The weeds are thickening, and the seedling plants are perishing or pining by the voraciousness of insects and the radiance of the Sun— My young peach trees and the buds and grafts on my Apple-stocks, are arrested in their growth by swarms of Aphides, and I have not one seedling of the present year, the growth of which gives me confidence that it will survive the next winter.— The leading shoot from the apple bud, which after a year’s insertion came out the first of August last, is the only plant the vegetation of which continues rapid and thrifty— It has grown 42 inches, since the first of May— I finished my answer to the Committee of the Anti-Masonic Convention in Vermont; but although nearly the whole day in my chamber, I accomplished nothing, and cannot rouse myself from the state of mental torpidity into which I have fallen.
18. IV:30. Thursday.

I resumed my labours of exercise in my Garden and Nursery, by digging there and eradicating weeds for about two hours before Breakfast—while the radiance of the Sun could be yet indured— My atchievements were to open a trench between two Rows of my growing Elm trees; and to plant a row of steep’d currants to ascertain if their power of vegetation is extinct— My unknown plant has been uprooted, by the wind, or by an invisible agent who does me great damage— The insects upon my Apple, Peach and Cherry trees are desolating— Charles went to Boston and returned to dine— At noon I bathed and swam at D. Greenleaf’s wharf, notwithstanding my Catarrh. Had an afternoon visit from Dr Spooner of Dorchester; a Son of my old friend Dr William Spooner of Boston— Alpheus Spear was here, and settled with me for the last Quarters rent of the Mount-Wollaston-farm— I told him that Mr Brigham the Parish Assessor had taken the opinion of Mr Metcalf the Lawyer at Dedham, that Parish Assessors may lawfully assess the taxes upon the owners in fee of Lands, and not upon Leasehold Tenants— That I must therefore pay the Parish tax on the Mount
Wollaston farm, and as he was bound by his lease to pay all the taxes I must look to him for repayment— He said he thought the tax unreasonable— He was willing to pay a reasonable tax of the usual amount. He was willing to leave it to three men, instead of twelve; but not Quincy men— He said Metcalf had not disputed but what the Assessors had the right to assess the tax on me; but advised him not to pay it, because he did not believe a jury would give their verdict against him.— The plain English of which is that the jury would consider me as a rich man, and Spear as a poor man, and would fleece me to clothe him— This is no uncommon idea of Justice— I told Spear I had been informed that he had been instigated to make this question with me, and asked him whether he thought it was honest, considering the express engagement in his lease, to refuse performing it, under a reliance that a Jury would favour him at my expense, because they would hold me for a rich and him for a poor man— He then said he believed the tax illegal. He supposed I had been told that he was the ringleader in all this disturbance about the parish tax; for he knew he had his enemies— But perhaps I had been misinformed— He was willing to do any thing that was reasonable, but he thought this tax unreasonable— I told him I had not yet paid the tax—but that I must pay it, and I should then apply to him again.— I took after this Conversation a short walk.
19. IV. Friday.

I spent about two hours again this morning in my Nursery and Garden preparing the ground at the bottom of my Nursery— This portion of time appears to be sufficient for my bodily exercise, but not for keeping my nursery in order. I deposited this morning a heap of Ohio Walnuts in the spot, where I had lately taken out a large Rock, and where yesterday rank weeds were shooting up to gigantic growth. Mr Gourgas was here with Elizabeth C. Adams— He mentioned to me the proposal which he had made to the Directors of the Lowell Railway Corporation, for indemnity to the Estate that was my brother’s at Medford, for the damage done by their passing through the land— He had asked 800 dollars— Mr Jackson’s proposal to him was to pay 115 dollars for one Acre and 25 rods of the land which they have taken, and 15 dollars for damage— He said they had settled with Mr Felt for the damage to his portion of the Estate, at less than this— He said that Dr Holbrook’s bill against my brother’s Estate was yet unpaid; and that was the only remaining debt— He spoke also of the Lands in the State of Vermont, and left with me a letter and account of Portus Baxter, the last Agent employed by my brother in that concern— Judge Cranch was also here. He has been visiting his own and his wife’s relations at Boston, Portsmouth, Haverhill, and New-Bedford— Proposes to depart next Monday, upon his return to Washington— I lost my bath and swim; but towards Evening rode with John Kirke, and took Mary Louisa with me to Solomon Thayer’s at Braintree— Saw his field of Ray Wheat as he calls it—nearly ready to reap. He expects to have 150 bushels from 1 1/2 Acre. He sowed 1 1/2 bushel to the Acre— He had a field of Corn, looking uncommonly well, and from which he had cut Off Suckers— He shewed me two large button-wood trees, which he told me were 33 years old, and which he had stuck into the ground, when about the size of a walking Stick. Also a very large Apple tree which he called the Turnip Apple 40 years old, and grafted from a tree on Norton Quincy’s farm, which tree no longer exists— I brought some slips from his tree, home with me, and in the Evening Charles budded one Stock in my Nursery from them.
20. IV.15. Saturday.

Finished the preparation of my ground at the bottom of the Nursery, and planted a row of cherry-stones, cherries and Black mulberries in the Garden at the gate of the Nursery—deposited in the Oak and walnut bed a small basket full of large Ohio Walnuts, and removed stumps of old Peach trees.— A person by the name of Callender, from New-York, connected with J. H. Colton and Co. Stationers and Map publishers and with S. Stiles and Co Engravers and Printers, brought me an engraved table of weights comparative, by a person named Henderson, which he gave out as a new invention, and which he wished to leave with me to obtain a recommendation of it by me as a useful discovery— I declined taking it—believing it not to be new, nor useful; but of that, observing that the Officers at the custom houses and merchants would be much better than I could be— I added that I had made it a rule to give no certificates of recommendation to new Inventions— He left with me pocket maps of the City of New-York, and of the Mexican Province of Texas— He told me the Cholera was or very soon would be in the City of New-York— Mrs Frothingham with her eldest Son was here this afternoon. I went to Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s to ask his Son Price Greenleaf to come, and bud, two or three apple-trees for me— He was at work in his Nursery, and promised to come Monday afternoon. He is working like an Ant or a Bee, and will make a Paradise of a Wilderness— Mrs Adams was able to sit up great part of this day, but not to leave her chamber.
21. IV:15. Sunday.

Mr Charles Brooks of Hingham preached this morning from Revelations 22.9. Worship God—and in the afternoon from Hebrews 13.8. [“]Jesus Christ, the same yesterday, and to day, and forever.” Both these Sermons were very pleasing to me; and they were exceedingly well delivered— But Mr Brooks is not a favourite with others— The argument of the morning discourse was that the duty of worshiping God, arises not from the command in the Scriptures, but from the necessities of man’s Nature— That of the afternoon Sermon, was the grandeur, the simplicity, the unalterable sublimity, and unchangeable perfection of the character of Jesus Christ— There were passages in both, that I thought eloquent and pathetic, and deep attention was paid to them by the Auditory— Mr Brooks was engaged to dine with Judge Cranch at Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s— I was anxiously desirous of devoting the whole day to religious meditations, and I feel that desire growing upon me, more earnestly from week to week, but I was deeply disappointed— I read the first Sermon of the fourth Volume of Saurin—on the Study of Religion— I thought it worthy of being read over and over— There was a written note in the book importing that the former owner of it had read this Sermon the 20th. of July 1783—yesterday was fifty years—and that he had read it a second time in October 1784— It might be profitably read by any sincere Christian three times over, and then profitably read again— It is an admirable discourse upon the duty of connecting practical moral purposes with all study of religion— I began also to read Milman’s History of the Jews, of which I had read some chapters last Winter at Washington; but with so little attention that I now began it anew— I was interrupted by a visit from Mr Degrand, and Mr Simmons a lawyer of Roxbury, who took up the remainder of the day— Their object was to obtain from me some declaration or certificate which might contribute to secure the re-election of Genl. H. A. S. Dearborn, as a member of the House of Representatives of the United States— He has failed upon three successive trials, by the want of a very small number of votes—twice of less than one hundred of more than 4000— The opposition to General Dearborn is Anti-Masonic— He is not a Mason, but in his opinions is opposed to the Masonic Institution; but he has not been able to steer impartially between the two parties, who in the district
which he lately represented, and in that for which he is now a Candidate, are nearly equally divided— The Anti-Masons are under the impression that he had deceived them, and there has been apparent inconsistency in his conduct on the occasion, at different times— Deception is not in his character, for he is candid and open-hearted. These gentlemen urged that my name was used to influence the election against General Dearborn, and they wished some document from me to counteract that influence— I told them that I had a very friendly regard for General Dearborn, and thought him a very valuable member of Congress— That I regretted the opposition to his re-election, and should be gratified if he should ultimately succeed— But I had made it a rule since I had occupied the Station of President of the United States, not to interfere in any political elections—that there was a peculiar delicacy which restrained me from any interference between the Anti-Masons and General Dearborn; but that I had in conversation with some of the leading Antimasons expressed my opinions and wishes as being favourable to him— Mr Simmons appeared to acquiesce in this determination— Degrand pressed me by various arguments but I persevered in refusal. They walked with me in my Garden and Nursery, and left me not long before nine in the Evening— We had much conversation upon the subjects of Masonry and Anti-Masonry, on which I hold it necessary to keep a perpetual guard upon myself, against falling into excess— The controversy is in itself so exciting to the Passions, that the curb can never be relaxed with impunity— I regret that I cannot consistently with my principles, lend a hand to secure the Election of Dearborn, who is an honest-hearted and fair-minded man, and whose indiscretion is visited upon him severely.
22. V. Monday. Fahrenheit 95.

This was the quintessence of Summer, the hottest day of the Season. My first visitor was Mr George Veazie, with whom I settled an account. Then came the Revd. Mr Johnson from Weathersfield, Vermont an itinerant preacher of the gospel, with Mr Pittee an inhabitant of Quincy with whom I had not been before acquainted— Mr Johnson came to see me, partly from curiosity; and partly to converse with me upon the doctrines of grace, election and reprobation— The Trinity, the divine and human natures of Jesus Christ, and the influences of the Holy Spirit upon the Soul— Upon these topics he warmed himself, until he found it necessary to strip off his coat; but he had nothing new to say upon them— As usual his discourse consisted of a string of texts from Scripture, chiefly from the Epistles of Paul, and to which he could affix no precise meaning, and when I pressed him for definite ideas he said it was true, great was the mystery of godliness. He told me he had preached last Evening to the Orthodox Congregation of which Mr Smith is now the occasional Pastor; and that he had been preaching about the Country as far South as Maryland— He said that he approved of my opinions upon the subject of Masonry, and had been in favour of my election as President, though without meddling much with politics— I told him that was altogether proper, and that with regard to my creed, that my judgment was not wholly under my own controul— That my faith must be subject to my judgment, and that I could believe nothing contrary to my reason, and not intelligibly revealed— Mr Johnson was here at least two hours, and all the time discussing these questions— He finally left me, I believe, because I ceased to
reply. Judge and Mrs Cranch came and took leave— To morrow they depart, upon their return to Washington— Mrs Lucy Greenleaf was with them— Mr Price Greenleaf came this afternoon, and budded for me nine seedling Stocks of Apple-trees— Three from the Mount Wollaston Apple tree of Solomon Thayer—three from the Harvest Apple-tree, and three from the Gloria Mundi at his father’s— And one Stock in the Garden, with the Mount Wollaston— Mr Thomas Greenleaf and his two daughters paid us an evening visit— Mrs Adams rode out; the first time these ten days— Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine.
23. IV:15. Tuesday— Bath and swim.

The drought continues and grows intense— The day was clear. The Sun parching, but the atmosphere cool—the wind varying from the North to North East and Northwest. At 5 in the morning I bathed and swam five minutes at the wharf—could spend but little time in the Garden and Nursery— Trees drooping and dying in numbers— I leave the weeds growing, to save if possible some of them— Weeds bid defiance to the Sun— I found a whitish green Caterpillar worm half an inch long and growing stripping the twigs of the willow in the Summer house Cellar, of their leaves—destroyed about fifty of them. Numbered my Earthen Pots from 1 to 10— Morning visit from Mr Bailey— The Ladies had visits from Mrs Davis daughter of Mr Benjamin Bussey, and Mrs Inglis a Scottish Lady—from Mrs Miller, and Miss Ann Quincy.— Mrs Adams had an attack of the Erysipelas, fallen into her foot, and also in the right eye, and is again confined to her chamber.— I wrote to Alexander H. Everett, and walked towards Evening to Mr Quincy’s gate— Read a few Letters of Madame de Sevigné.
24. IV. Wednesday— Bath and swim

This morning there was every appearance of copious rain, but it was a disappointment— There was a sprinkling of less than five minutes early this morning, and another this Evening; and in the interval a blazing Sun, a baking atmosphere and a sultry flat calm— I bathed and swam about Sunrise, and was caught in the shower. Visited my garden and Nursery, where many of my most promising seedling plants are drooping, withering and burning to cinders— The Indian corn too begins to roll up— I endeavoured to resume the biography of my father, but was compelled by intense heat to desist— After dinner I read the prefaces and notices of the latest Edition that I have of the Letters of Madame de Sevigné— This Lady never imagined the celebrity which she attained. Her Letters were all private— None of them published in her Lifetime— None of them intended for publication— Her husband was killed in a duel when she had been married only four or five years, and she lived nearly half a century a widow; and died in 1696 at the age of 70. She was of noble birth, nearly related to Cardinal de Retz, and in affluence— But not much noticed at the magnificent Court of Louis the 14th. and but for the posthumous publication of her Letters, would have speedily passed into total oblivion— Her Cousin Bussy-Rabutin, a man of fatuitous pretensions to literary eminence, of vicious life, her slanderer because she rejected him as a lover, first published in his Memoirs her Letters to him, just after her death—and by a just retribution of public Sentiment raised her reputation at the expense of his own— So little was known of her that Bayle, who wished to put her into his Dictionary could not obtain facts relating to her sufficient to make an article of her life— Thirty years after her death, and twenty after that of her daughter, in 1726 a small portion of her Letters to her were first published by an act of treachery to Madame de Simiane her Grand daughter to whom they belonged— Many others have been
collected, and added to subsequent editions, and many of those of her Correspondents are included in this Edition by Grouvelle, published in 1812. Madame de Sevigné’s Letters are by many thought the most perfect models of epistolary style extant—and that is my opinion of them— Mr George W. Beale was here this evening.
25. IV:15. Thursday.

I bathed again at the wharf this morning before Breakfast; but with much reluctance am becoming convinced that the cold bath in any form rather injures than improves my health— After breakfast I visited my garden and Nursery; dug out sundry rock like Stones from a central Western bed, and planted there 3 [symbols] five more of which I also planted in a Pot. N. 9. I cease to eradicate the weeds in the hope that they may save from the drought some of the seedling trees which yet survive— Many Oaks and Walnuts the Acorns and nuts of which were planted last Autumn, are just now coming up— They have not time to form stems before the frosts, which will bear the winter. Is not the time of planting most important? Nature plants the seed when the fruit is ripe, and its natural covering decayed— Many of the Elm seeds which I gathered and planted between the 15th and 30th. of May came up in fourteen days— Some in ten; but the walnut and Oak, baffle all my care. Even my Ashes are drooping with the drought— This day was cool, with an Easterly wind, but no rain. I read the notices, prefatory to the last Edition that I possess of Madame de Sevigné’s Letters— Mr and Madame de Coulanges and Corbinelli— For it has been the privilege of this Lady not only to attain a posthumous immortality herself, but to have conferred it upon several of her friends— I wrote a few lines of biography— My wife, who is yet confined to her chamber, received a Letter from our daughter Mary at Philadelphia— She is coming with her husband and daughter Fanny here— Mrs Edward Miller, Louisa Smith and Elizabeth Adams were here in the Evening.
26. IV. Friday— Boston— French Theatre at the Tremont— Zampa.

Cool. Clear Easterly wind and continued drought. Louisa Smith dined with us, and gave me from Mr Lemuel Brackett’s Garden a Cherry plum, of which I plant the Stone in Pot 10. with the seeds of several Black Mulberries and 5 [symbols] She gave me also the seeds of 4 large gooseberries, from the same garden, which I propose in like manner to plant— This was the 36th. anniversary of my Marriage. In the Evening I went to Boston with my wife, my Son Charles and his wife; we took tea at Mr Frothingham’s, and then with Mrs Frothingham and her eldest Son Thomas went to the Tremont Theatre where a French company from New-Orleans are performing— The Play was a new Melo-drama, operatized, called Zampa, or the Marble Bride— The old Story of Don Juan, only metamorphosing the Statue into a woman and adapting a suitable and easy Story to the change— The author is named Harold, and it is said to have had 150 Representations at Paris— The Music was fashionable and dull; in the Rossini Style, without harmony, without Sentiment, without humour, without passion; and like all the new music I have heard for the last ten years a general gargle for sore throats. There can be no clearer proof of the degeneracy of musical taste than the desertion of the Matrimonio Segreto, the Molinara, Theodore, Tulipano, Gretri, Mehul d’Alayrac, and Boïeldieu, for such trashy, warbling, trilling, insignificance as this— We yawned over it, till eleven O’Clock, and reached home a quarter of an hour after midnight.
27. VI. Saturday.

Continued drought— A clear Sun, the whole day, with an atmosphere not above Summer heat. I could make only a short visit to my Garden and Nursery; where the useful plants are perishing with heat and thirst, and parasite weeds are flourishing— The effect of this weather is to superinduce languor and listlessness and involuntary indolence— I attempted to write but could not succeed— I read the Eulogy upon Madame de Sevigné by Madame de Brisson, which in 1777 obtained the prize at the Academy of Marseilles, and worthy of the prize and of the subject. Who this Madame de Brisson was, I cannot ascertain— I read also the Correspondence between Madame de Sevigné and Bussy-Rabutin from 1647 to 1657. Seventeen Letters— They are very indelicate, but full of wit— The first written by her immediately after the birth of her Son, and in the 22d. year of her own age is especially remarkable, as characteristic of the person, of her Country, and of the time in which she lived— She was a virtuous woman and maintained an unblemished reputation through a long widowhood, having lost her husband when she was under 26. Bussy himself and many others made love to her in vain— But it was a very profligate age in regard to the intercourse between the sexes, and this Letter shews how vicious manners infect the conversation even of those who resist their influence upon the conduct— A married woman of 22. who at this time should write to a male cousin such a Letter as this could have little virtue to preserve— Bussy’s answer is in a corresponding tone, and such as a young married woman could not read without a blush—
28. V. Sunday.

Heard Mr Whitney from Luke 12.48. “For unto whomsoever much is given, of him shall be much required.”—and from Matthew 5.8. [“]Blessed are the pure in heart: for they shall see God.”— In the morning discourse an earnest exhortation against intemperance found its place— I read the second Sermon of the fourth Volume of Saurin—upon the love of Country. He takes his text and his model of Patriotism from Nehemiah— This discourse is remarkable because Saurin himself was a French refugee from the Edict of Nantes’s revocation, and Pastor of a French Protestant Church at the Hague— Holland was not his native Country nor that of his French Auditors— His Patriot is Nehemiah—like them an exile from his own Country, but permitted to return to it; which they were not— Saurin analyses from the Story of Nehemiah the principles of Patriotism and separately discusses them—as composed of a Spirit of 1. devotion 2. reformation 3. mortification 4. Prudence 5 Vigilance 6. Firmness 7. Disinterestedness— There are two distinct addresses, one to the natives of the Netherlands, and the other to his own Countrymen the French Refugees; who he says are deprived of the Privilege of exercising the virtue of Patriotism— This is a very curious example of the modifications with which time, place and circumstances affect the Sentiments of men in their social relations. I read also the remainder of Book 1. the Patriarchal Age, and Book 2. Israel in Egypt of Milman’s History of the Jews— He begins with Abraham— There are two difficulties to all modernized Histories of the Jews— Neither the facts, nor the characters are subjects of free discussion or enquiry— All is marvellous—all is miraculous, and the attempt to account for the Events from natural causes and by natural means strikes at the root of the whole History— The Narrative is always at War with physical Nature, and the morality is all referable to the single principle of the Will of God. Depart but one hair’s breadth from that, and all moral principle in the Bible is extinct— What is the crime of eating an apple? disobedience to the Will of God— What is the virtue of butchering a man’s own beloved Son? Obedience to the Will of God. The consequence of which is that we must approve of vicious actions as virtuous,
and censure good deeds as crimes— From this difficulty Mr Milman does not escape— Nor does he exactly discern the line within which this rule must be restricted— The subversion of moral principle, is admissible only so far as the divine Will is clearly and distinctly ascertained. The only fair and almost blameless character among the Patriarchs is Joseph, and he perhaps cannot be fully justified for telling his two dreams— But I am wandering— I walked this Evening to Mrs T. B. Adams’s, and spent an hour there— Mr Beale, his son and eldest daughter, Mr Gourgas, Louisa Smith and Elizabeth Adams was there— The Day was clear and cold with Clouds of dust— Mr Whitney gave notice that the communion would be administered next Sunday.
29. IV. Monday.

The Sun rose with a sky perfectly clear— Clouds were gathering all the Morning— There was a very light sprinkling in the afternoon, and again late in the Evening. I found the heat of the Sun too oppressive to remain long in the garden this Morning— After dinner I planted a third row of Ohio Walnuts, dry Mazzard Cherries and Stones, Black Mulberry and Red Currant seed all kneaded together in moistened Earth—at the cleared off Strawberry patch in the Garden, at the entrance of the Nursery— The effect of the drought upon my seedling plants is desolating— They perish like the Soldiers of Napoleon upon the retreat from Moscow; and I mourn them as if they were animated beings. Very few seedlings of the present year are left alive— Many of former years which I had hoped were beyond the reach of Sun or frost are withering, and all are drooping— The ground is mere dust, or covered with rank weeds.— Towards Evening I walked to Mrs T. B. Adams’s, and gave her a Letter from her Son the Lieutenant at Pittsburg— There was a room full of company there— Charles went to Boston and returned to dine— I wrote to R. Rush—
30. IV:15. Tuesday.

William Field came and settled with me his Rent for the House and Farm, at the foot of Penn’s Hill, for the half year ending 31. March last. Mr Hardy and Mr Clark came and announced themselves as members of the Anti-Masonic County Committee for the County of Middlesex, and their object was to consult me with regard to the Anti-Masonic nomination for the Offices of Governor and Lieutenant Governor of the Commonwealth, for the ensuing year. First to ascertain whether I would consent to be nominated by the Anti-Masonic Convention— I told them that I had explicitly declined, from a belief upon full deliberation that I can render more useful service to the Anti-Masonic Cause, and to the Public, as a member of the House of Representatives of the United States than I could as Governor of the Commonwealth— They then enquired whether I should approve of the nomination by that convention of Edward Everett— I said that I entertained a high opinion of the talents and integrity of Mr Everett—that I believed he would do honour to the Office of Governor, and if he should be nominated, I should be much gratified by the success of the nomination. I said it would however be for the consideration of the Convention, whether after supporting two years in succession, Mr Lathrop against Governor Lincoln, it would be just and fair now to abandon him— They thought Mr Lathrop was not himself solicitous of a re-nomination, and they believed him to be so unpopular, that if nominated he could not succeed— They proposed to visit Mr Bailey, and enquired what I should think of him as a Candidate for the Office of Lieutt. Governor— I said I had great regard and esteem for Mr Bailey, who had been for many years an intimate and confidential friend of mine. It would give me great pleasure if he should obtain the Office of Lieutenant Governor. They said Mr Fuller was their Candidate for Lieutenant Governor last year; but as he and Mr Everett were
both Inhabitants of Middlesex County, there would be a difficulty in pressing them both for the first and second Offices of the State— They spoke of Dr Ripley’s and Bernard Whitman’s Masonic Addresses— Ripley said he would sooner be cut in two than violate his Masonic Oaths and Whitman gave out that Anti-Masonry was nothing more than Orthodoxy in disguise.— I said that perhaps the Anti-Masons would do well to consider whether they might not much strengthen their vote for Governor, by taking up Mr Armstrong as their candidate with him— Armstrong is now Lieutenant Governor, and was elected by the National Republicans for his Orthodoxy— Perhaps that party which is very numerous might be conciliated, by adopting him as their Candidate— They said this would deserve much consideration— Mr Hardy said if Armstrong was not a Mason, he might vote for him; but not if he was— They asked me, if I would mention to them any other person whom I should prefer as Candidate for Governor, if there should be insuperable objections to taking up with Mr Everett— I said that was a matter of great delicacy— I did not immediately think of any person, unless it should be Mr Webster— They thought he looked higher, and might perhaps be President of the United States— There was a gentle rain last Night, and copious Showers this Morning— The Sky cleared off again this Evening.
31. IV.25. Wednesday.

I was called this morning from the Garden to a visit from Mrs Boylston. She brought a notification from the President of the University Quincy, to her son, the father of Ward Nicholas Boylston, that his, Ward’s absences are excessive; that he has been admonished on account of them, and that unless he change his conduct in this respect he must leave college— Mrs Boylston is very much distressed at this notice, and knows not what to do, to save this child from ruin— There was already a note of censure upon him last year, which then gave her and me much concern, and upon which I expostulated with him, and he promised well; but without effect— If he should be dismissed from the College he will be ruined— As however it appears extremely probable that this will be done I asked Mrs Boylston what her intentions were in that event— She said she should depend altogether upon me— I said one of three things would be necessary— To put him into a merchant’s Counting house— To send him to his father at Princeton, to make a farmer out of him or to send him to Sea, and work him into a Mariner— She did not seem to relish either, but there will be not much choosing. She said she would send him over to me here next Monday, and asked me to talk with him, which I promised, though I am but too well assured, it will be preaching to the winds— The boys mother is far gone in a consumption— His younger brother Thomas is to go to school one year more, and then to a Merchant— I walked this Evening to Mr Quincy’s gate for my complement of exercise.

Day— Like that of the two preceding Months, excepting that under the blaze of the Sun, I cannot spend so much time, or labour with so much industry in my Garden and Nursery— The drought has killed so many of my seedling Plants that I become discouraged and despond of ever accomplishing any thing. My state of health however forbids my return with intense application to mere sedentary occupations. I have daily admonitions not only of the advance of old age, but of a probable early termination of my life— I am losing my Sleep, and losing much of the refreshment of Sleep— The thorn or nettle in the flesh which unrelentingly pursues me, makes my Sleep in the Night restless and unquiet— I rise before day light in the morning, and am half an hour fitting myself to read or write— Then I consequently doze many times in the course of the day—and on retiring weary and oppressed for the night, still am long before I slumber— The machine is indeed nearly worn out, and I have had so much of enjoyment of Life, and by the blessing of God so small a share of its evils, that I have no right to address to Heaven any other prayer than that of a peaceable remnant and an easy passage.
